text: The Summer Conference on Applied Data Science (SCADS) focuses on AI research to assist US Intelligence Community data analysts.
SCADS brings together around fifty personnel each year, including faculty, graduate students, and industry professionals.
The grand challenge for 2024 is to create tailored daily reports (TLDRs) for knowledge workers in the IC.
Efforts include automatic summarization, recommendation systems, and human-machine interaction.
Research areas will focus on explainability, contextualization, and dataset creation.
Automatic summarization involves extractive and abstractive techniques.
Sentence embeddings are used to improve extractive summarization.
Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) addresses hallucinations in multi-document summarization.
Temporal elements in RAG pipelines ensure up-to-date information.
Fact-checking tools like SummaC and QAFactEval are used to detect hallucinations.
The document includes sections on recommendation systems, emphasizing personalized content for TLDRs.
Human evaluation is crucial for assessing the quality of generated summaries.
Explainability in recommender systems enhances transparency and user trust.
The document discusses the potential use of multi-modal data in summarization, such as video and audio.
A method to incorporate user feedback in recommendation models is essential to address bias.
Neural networks can be modular to meet SCADS Grand Challenge objectives.
The use of reinforcement learning can optimize recommendation systems in dynamic environments.
Named entity recognition is crucial in linking items to knowledge graphs for improved recommendations.
Techniques like VideoGPT enhance video summarization capabilities.
A hybrid summarization approach combining extractive and abstractive methods can improve accuracy.
The document outlines a comprehensive survey on dialogue summarization data sets.
Summarizing non-text data, such as network packets, is critical for a holistic TLDR system.
The SCADS program also focuses on the impact of different prompting styles in summarization systems.
SCADS researchers use Deep Knowledge-Aware Network (DKN) for news recommendation.
